qas.question: Who wrote the "Principles of Classification and a Classification of Mammals?
Simpson laid the systematics of mammal origins and was taught universally up until the end of what century?
Which new concept has greatly taken over Simpsons much debated theoretical systematization?

plausible_answers.text: a systematics of mammal origins and relationships

qas.question: What did Simpson lay out that was universally taught until 1945?

plausible_answers.text: "Principles of Classification and a Classification of Mammals"

qas.question: What was the original source for the paleontoligical record?

plausible_answers.text: the paleontological record has been recalibrated

qas.question: What happened since the classification by the AMNH?
What taxonomy took over AMNH's debated systematization?
Up until what century were cladistics universally taught?

context: <a0_0>George Gaylord Simpson<a0_0/>'s <b4_0>"Principles of Classification and a Classification of Mammals"<b4_0/> (AMNH Bulletin v. 85, 1945) was the original source for the taxonomy listed here. Simpson laid out <b3_0>a systematics of mammal origins and relationships<b3_0/> that was universally taught until the <b7_0>end of the <a1_0>20th<a1_0/> century<b7_0/>. Since Simpson's classification, <b5_0>the paleontological record has been recalibrated<b5_0/>, and the intervening years have seen much debate and progress concerning the theoretical underpinnings of systematization itself, partly through the new concept of <a2_0><b6_0>cladistics<b6_0/><a2_0/>. Though field work gradually made Simpson's classification outdated, it remained the closest thing to an official classification of mammals.
